## Who can claim a refund

There is no need to make a claim if you are currently acting as the deputy and still paying supervision fees. You will be refunded any money due as part of your annual supervision fee calculation.

If the person has died, you can make a claim if you’re:

* the executor of the will
* the administrator of the estate, if there is no administrator

A family member may make a claim if there is no executor or administrator.
You will need to show …

The refund must be paid to the estate.

## How much you’ll get
How much you get depends on when you paid the fees. You’ll also get 0.5% interest.

You can still claim a refund even if you don’t know when you paid the fees.

[click here](#) for more information on how much you'll likely get

## How to claim
It takes about 10 minutes to claim online.

Before you claim you’ll need:
* the will or grant of probate document 
If you don't have it, you may be able to [Find the person's  will or probate document online](https://www.gov.uk/search-will-probate)
the donor’s UK bank account number and sort code
* something else

If you need help or more information to claim online then you can call the Refunds Helpline.

heading: Claim a deputyship supervision refund online
lede: You can get part of your supervision fee back if you've overpaid assessment and supervisions fees from 1 April 2007 to 31 March 2017.  You must claim your refund by 1 February 2021.
